Introduction

The purpose of this document is to provide clarity to all staff across the Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust (MSEFT) on the correct procedure to follow when notified of a trans patient and how to manage paper and electronic health records and patient data.

The policy supports the concept of shared responsibility between departments ensuring the confidentiality and safety of the trans patient, whilst ensuring consistency and coherence to national and legal requirements.
This document applies to all staff employed and non-employed by MSEFT who are providing a service within the Trust.
All trans patients are protected in the Trust and through this policy regardless of identity characteristics.
This document supports the objectives of the Trust's Equality, Diversity and Inclusion (EDI) Strategy 2021-2025.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:
Provide clarity to all staff across MSEFT on the correct procedure to follow when managing paper and electronic health records for trans patients.
Ensure all staff are made aware of the importance of following the correct protocol in managing patient health records for trans patients.

data.text: Definition of trans

Trans people have a gender identity or gender expression that differs from their sex assigned at birth. Some trans people who desire medical assistance to transition from one sex to another identify as transsexual. Transgender is often shortened to trans.

Trans is used as an umbrella term to describe people whose gender is not the same as, or does not sit comfortably with, the sex they were assigned at birth. Trans people may describe themselves using one or more of a variety of terms including but not limited to transgender, transsexual, gender-queer, gender-fluid, non-binary, gender-variant, crossdresser, genderless, a-gender, non-gender, third gender, bi- gender, trans man, trans woman, trans masculine, trans feminine and neutrois.

In addition to including people whose gender identity is the opposite of their assigned sex (trans men and trans women), many trans people experience gender dysphoria, a mental, physical or social discomfort with sex assigned at birth, and/or their physical body that most often causes distress and can impact on mental health. Some people seek medical support such as hormone replacement therapy, gender reassignment surgery, or psychiatric treatment. Not all trans people desire this level of support.
Roles and responsibilities within the Trust

Equality Diversity and Inclusion Group – provides a forum within the Trust to address and raise awareness of the diverse needs of patients, visitors and staff across the Trust and to ensure equality and fairness for all.

Head of Information Governance & Data Protection Officer – operationally responsible for the development and updating of Information Governance management frameworks and policies in line with local and national requirements. The Trust's appointed Data Protection Officer reports to the highest level of organisational management via the Chief Information Officer.
Information Governance Manager - supports the Data Protection Officer and SIRO functions, and is responsible for:
Overseeing the organisation and implementation of the Trust's information governance framework including the Data Protection Act (DPA) and all current data protection legislation.
Managing the confidentiality and data protection components of the Data Security and Protection Toolkit, contributing to the annual assessment.
Supporting the roll out of information governance training including data protection awareness.

Ensuring, along with the SIRO, Information Security Leads and Information Governance Leads, that Information Asset Owners (IAOs) are nominated to manage local responsibilities under the DPA including confidentiality within their work area.
Chief Executive –is ultimately responsible for ensuring compliance with this policy.

Clinical Director – is responsible for reviewing any existing health records for trans patients and deciding if a clinical summary of the patient's previous clinical history is required for inclusion in the patient's post-trans health record.
Senior Information Risk Owner – Board appointed Director responsible for:
Serious data protection issues that are brought to the Board for discussion.
A lead or manager in place to organise and enforce the Trust's policy for data protection (refer to appendix 1 of MSBPO-18001 Information Governance and Management Policy for more details).
Caldicott Guardian – Board appointed Director responsible for:
Protecting the confidentiality of Personal Confidential Data (PCD) processed by the Trust, ensuring that all sites adhere to the highest practical standards for handling patient data.
Acting as the “conscience” of the Trust by actively supporting work to enable the use and sharing of PCD where appropriate and advising on lawful and ethical solutions.

Championing confidentiality, information sharing requirements and issues at Board level and, where appropriate, at a range of levels within the Trust's overall governance framework. (Refer to appendix 2 of MSBPO-18001 Information Governance and Management Policy for more details).

Deputy Director of Clinical Coding, Health Records and Data Quality - is responsible for ensuring the distribution of this policy and advising managers of the correct procedure in place across the Trust.
Department Managers – are responsible for the implementation of this policy at department level. This includes:
Identifying any training needs.
Ensuring staff are aware of the policy in place.
Liaising with relevant departments to ensure the correct procedure is followed.
Data Quality Team – are responsible for ensuring accurate recording of data on relevant PAS / EPR systems and liaising with third parties where appropriate.
Health Records Staff – are responsible for managing health records in accordance with this policy.

Digital Services Department – are responsible for the management of personal information being stored within the hospital's PAS / EPR systems that cannot be processed by the Data Quality team. This may include contacting third parties
where necessary.
Information Asset Owners – are responsible for the management of trans identification data held on their systems in line with this policy.
All staff handling health records and viewing patient demographics – are responsible for ensuring patient records are accurate. This includes:
Recording the correct information within the health records and on PAS / EPR systems.
Immediate escalation if any evidence of previous information prior to gender change is visible in the notes or available on PAS / EPR. An incident form must also be completed.
Equality Act 2010

The Equality Act 2010 legally protects people from discrimination in the workplace and in wider society. Under the Equality Act 2010, trans people who have, are currently, or have yet to transition, have legal protection against discrimination.
Gender Recognition Act 2004 Regulation 2018

The Gender Recognition Act allows trans people to gain legal recognition of their acquired gender by registering for a Gender Recognition Certificate (GRC). The application is made to the Gender Recognition Panel who will determine whether the GRCs should be issued on the basis that the applicant has lived in their gender for two years and intends to live the gender until death. An applicant does not have to have had gender reassignment surgery, but have been diagnosed as gender dysphoric. Where a full GRC had been issued to a person, the gender on the GRC becomes for all purposes their gender.
Prohibition on disclosure of information

The Gender Recognition Act has important implications for NHS Trusts, particularly in relation to the provisions on prohibition of disclosure of information relating to a person's application for a GRC or, if GRC is issued, their gender assigned at birth. Under section  of the Act, it is an offence for a person who has acquired, in an official capacity, protected information regarding an individual's gender identity to disclose that information to any other person. This clearly affects NHS Bodies as employees and in supply service to the public, as they are likely to acquire such information in relation to their employees or patients.
Process for registering a patient gender reassignment

When a patient changes gender, they are given a new NHS Number and must be registered as a new patient at their GP practice and all previous medical information relating to the patient needs to be transferred into a newly created health record. When the patient informs the practice they wish to amend their gender marker, the practice must inform the patient that this will involve a new NHS number being issued for them, which is not reversible, unless the individual concerned explicitly consents to continuing with the existing record. To revert back to their original gender, they would receive a third NHS number. The practice should confirm that this has been discussed with the patient when notifying Primary Care Support England (PCSE).
The process is:
A person of any gender who is aged at least 18 may make an application for a gender recognition certificate.
The application is to be determined by a Gender Recognition Panel.

An application must include a report made by a registered medical practitioner experienced within the field of gender dysphoria. Unless the applicant has undergone or is undergoing treatment for the purpose of modifying sexual characteristics, or treatment for that purpose has been prescribed or planned for the applicant.
If a Gender Recognition Panel grants an application, it must issue a gender recognition certificate to the applicant.

The patient can inform their GP, or directly inform the CCG that they are transitioning and in future they would be known by their correct name and gender. The GP/ CCG will then notify the PCSE that the patient wishes to change their information providing them with the Gender Recognition Certificate (GRC).

A new NHS Number will be generated by the National Back Office and this will then be passed to the patients GP. The GP will then create a new record using only post GRC information. Any information relating to the patient previous identity should not be included in the new record.
For those under 18 years that do not have a GRC their title and name can be changed on receipt of a valid change of name document but not the gender.
Where a patient provides evidence of their change of name and title but not a full GRC (e.g. Deed Poll) and requests their gender be updated the PAS / EPR

the gender should not be updated, however the patient should be advised that the PAS/EPR correspond to PDS/Primary Care records and that once a new NHS number has been issued a new registration would be made on PAS/EPR with gender displayed as per PDS. Patient gender should not be changed as this has implications for gender specific national screening programmes who derive demographic information from the PDS.
Process – NHS Trust – notification and records

When a NHS organisation has been notified of a patient's gender transition the following protocol will take place to ensure the security and safety of that patient and the privacy of this change meets UK Legislation.

If the patient is not already registered under their new details, it is the responsibility of the department managing the patient to register the patient as a new patient on the PAS as per local process. They should then notify the DQ Team who will investigate if there are any open care pathways that need to be transferred to the new patient number and liaise with the Clinical Director where appropriate.

A new folder should be started using the new NHS number generated by the GP. If the patient has active medical history the Clinical Director will be asked to summarise the history from the previous records without reference to personal data for inclusion in the post-trans health record. This should include any ongoing treatment, past medical history summary, vaccination and immunisation data, with the consent of the patient. If the patient refuses to have details of any existing medical condition added to their new record and that condition is not related to the gender reassignment process then the impact on the organisation's ability to treat the person for that medical condition and on any related prescriptions of medicines must be clearly explained.

It is the responsibility of the PAS/EPR team, and other Clinical systems Leads to ensure any open, on-going pathways are managed on both previous hospital number and newly created hospital number. Referrals, pathways and activity should be re-created on new hospital number ensuring patient's Referral to Treatment (RTT) period is consistent and accurate.

Once the investigation has taken place, the patient's former records will be stored securely within the Health Records library or electronic records system with a comment stating “Do not remove from shelf, contact Health Records Manager” and held for the appropriate retention period before disposal (see MSEPO – 20234 Health Records Policy).
There should be no link between the two records other than the summary written by the clinician.
Data Quality – NHS Trusts
It is the responsibility of the Data Quality department to follow this policy to meet the policy guidelines.
The Data Quality department is responsible for the investigation into patient records and would involve other departments if they deem necessary.
All Trust staff

If a member of staff outside of the Data Quality Department has confirmation of a gender transition they must contact the Data Quality department as a matter of urgency, informing them of all details and passing over any associated documentation confidentially and sensitively.
Safety and security

It is an offence for a person who has acquired protected information in an official capacity to disclose the information to any other person. You should always gain consent before disclosing this information, with permitted exceptions only when it is not possible to gain consent and is essential for the delivery of service.

Prior to a patient having obtained a new gender status under the GRA, it should be decided by the patient what demographic information is held within our systems and on their health records. These are to be amended to their preference. Gender within the electronic and physical records MUST remain untouched until the patient receives the GRC.

Clinicians should be advised that if any confusion occurs when addressing the patient, they should always discreetly ask the patient how they would like to be addressed, whilst being careful to avoid disclosing the trans status of the patient to others in doing so. If clinicians are unable to ascertain the patients preference, they could simply refer to the person in question using gender neutral terminology such as “the patient” or “they/their /them” so as to avoid distressing the patient by opting for terminology which the patient has not chosen.

data.text: Approval and implementation

This policy and guidelines will be approved by the Equality and Diversity Group, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Equality and Diversity Group of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
